cluster_relations.rel_desc: Public protest demonstrations act as catalysts driving social and political change.
Revolutions are also depicted as catalysts driving social and political change.
Revolutions are said to have transformed the political landscape of many countries.
Public protest demonstrations are described as a powerful tool that drives social and political change.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: from ancient times to the present day

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Revolutions are also framed as a powerful tool that drives social and political change.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: from ancient times to the present day

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject (typically a form of collective action or upheaval) acts as a catalyst that brings about sociopolitical change in the object society or political system.
args.justification: All five relations describe collective political actions (public protests or revolutions) as causal drivers that produce or transform sociopolitical conditions (social and political change, political landscape). Despite wording differences like 'drives' or 'transforms', they share the same predicate semantics of catalyzing sociopolitical change.

Each relation links a form of political collective action (protests or revolutions) to resulting changes in sociopolitical structures or landscapes, fitting a class focused on causes of sociopolitical change.
The relations explicitly describe causal influence (acting as catalysts, driving or transforming) from political actions to social and political outcomes, which belongs under a broad causality group.
